awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Self-Assembly and Aggregate Formation in Stratified Fluids
awd_abstract_narration:
The atmospheres, lakes, and oceans of our world typically involve density variability, with layers of lighter fluid sitting on top of heavier fluid.  In this project, we are exploring a novel mechanism we have discovered through which particles suspended within such layered systems are seen to attract each other and self-assemble, forming large disc like clusters.  The mechanism for this attraction involves fluid flows which the particles themselves create from being in a layered fluid.  Such clusters occur ubiquitously in lakes and oceans, where they can provide food sources for a variety of organisms, or result in concentrations of polluting particles. The origins of these clusters may well lie within this new aggregate formation mechanism under exploration within this award. Graduate students will be involved in the project. 

Specifically, the award will undertake a combined theoretical, numerical, and experimental investigation of a newly discovered hydrodynamic interaction between particles in a stratified ambient environment. Recent experimental work by the PIs at the UNC Joint Fluids Lab have demonstrated that passive particles suspended in a density-stratified environment interact through self-induced flows which can result in approaching  one and another over time until coming into contact. Collections of many particles tend to aggregate and self-assemble into large-scale 2D structures due to this newly identified attraction mechanism. The project aims to characterize this newly-identified interaction effect in nature for the first time, through novel asymptotic methods, numerical simulations, and careful experimentation.  The research will explore the complex interplay between diffusion, advection, and geometry (through physical boundary conditions) in inducing new collective phenomena. This requires developing novel computational, asymptotic, and experimental methods for extracting quantitative predictions from the parent Navier-Stokes equations coupled through the viscous stress tensor to particles suspended in stratified environments. The new asymptotic methods developed as part of this proposal will also prove useful for a wider range of problems in fluid dynamics and potential theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Vertical density stratification naturally occurs in oceans, lakes, and atmospheres. Its effect on dynamics of particles spans a vast range of spatio-temporal scales and is important to many natural processes, such as the carbon cycle.  In this project, we have identified and studied a new mechanism for particle aggregation in stratified fluids.  While the discovery was initially made in our experiment, we have now completed a validated theory from first principles that rationalizes and reproduces our observations.  The aggregation process requires no complex physics, but emerges naturally from diffusion-induced flows that arise when density stratification meets a complex geometric boundary, such as a sphere.  The work has investigated both solid and porous particles.

Intellectual Merit: In this award we have discovered a new physical mechanism by which particles can aggregate in a stratified fluid. Using techniques of mathematical modeling, we have developed a theory to explain the observed particle aggregation, and benchmarked particle-level and aggregate-level predictions with direct laboratory-scale measurements conducted in parallel.  Tools from applied mathematics were used to derive new analytical expressions for the diffusion-induced flow in specific regimes, and allowed for benchmarking of computational analysis that extended the predictions over a wider range of parameters. The work has advanced the knowledge of particle motion in stratified fluid environments and enrichened the mathematical and computational techniques available to analyze such flows.

Broader Impact: This award has fostered the collaboration of faculty, postdocs, and students across disciplines and institutions.  In particular, it has provided opportunities for undergraduates to become involved in mentored research experiences that have developed skills in applied mathematics, computation, and physical experimentation. Furthermore, our fundamental discoveries will have implications for natural transport processes in oceans and lakes that are fundamental to the natural cycles of the planet.  Elucidation of the key mechanisms for mass transport in such environments, and their associated implications on the biological and climate health of the planet, are critical to constructing a holistic understanding of such environmental processes.
